description: Hard - Complex Analysis and Critical Evaluation

questions.question: Analyze the strategic paradox Rome faced after completely dominating the Mediterranean (SELECT ALL THAT APPLY)
options: With no external rivals to fight, internal Roman politics became more competitive and contentious
Wealth flowing from empire enriched successful commanders, increasing their political power
Competition for control of lucrative provinces created factional conflicts within the Republic
Rome's military superiority ensured permanent peace throughout the empire
The expansion that secured Rome externally created instability internally
Complete dominance removed the external threats that had unified Roman political factions
questions.text_reference: Section 10 - The Beginning of Rome's New Era

questions.question: How did Rome's treatment of different rivals reflect changing strategic thinking over time? (SELECT ALL THAT APPLY)
options: Rome treated all rivals identically throughout the period
Macedonia was reduced and restricted but allowed to exist initially under the 196 BCE treaty
After 30 years, Rome destroyed Macedonia completely when challenged again
Carthage moved from being a contained rival to being viewed as an existential threat requiring elimination
Early treaties with firm restrictions later proved insufficient as Roman attitudes hardened
questions.text_reference: Sections 3 and 8 - Comparison of Roman policies

questions.question: What role did information control and historical narrative play in Rome's actions toward Carthage? (SELECT ALL THAT APPLY)
options: We know about Carthage primarily through hostile Greek and Roman sources
Cato and others used selective invocation of the Second War to shape political opinion
Carthaginian destruction eliminated Carthaginian historical records and perspectives permanently
Archaeological evidence has recovered extensive Carthaginian written records and literary works
This loss means our understanding of Carthage is inherently biased
Carthaginian historians documented their civilization extensively before Rome's destruction

questions.question: Evaluate the relationship between Masinissa's harassment of Carthage and Rome's eventual conquest. Which interpretations are supported by the text? (SELECT ALL THAT APPLY)
options: Rome actively opposed Masinissa's territorial expansion and demanded he cease attacks immediately
Masinissa was seeking to establish sole control over all of North Africa independent of Rome's influence
The harassment kept Carthage distracted and weakened over decades
Rome deliberately tolerated or encouraged Masinissa's aggression as strategic policy
Masinissa acted completely independently of Roman strategic calculations
Masinissa was effectively a tool of Roman policy toward Carthage

questions.question: How did the economic character of Carthage versus Rome shape their conflict? (SELECT ALL THAT APPLY)
options: Carthage was fundamentally merchant and trade-based in its wealth
Rome and Carthage both relied equally on maritime commerce as their primary economic foundation
Carthage's recovered commerce was viewed as threatening by Roman interests
Rome actively encouraged Carthaginian trade as a way to create economic interdependence and prevent war
Economic cooperation and commercial treaties were the primary factors preventing earlier conflict
Economic difference may have contributed to Rome viewing Carthage as culturally alien and fundamentally incompatible

questions.question: Analyze Flamininus's diplomatic approach to Greece versus Rome's eventual destruction of Carthage. What do these contrasts suggest about Roman strategic thinking? (SELECT ALL THAT APPLY)
options: Rome could be flexible and respectful toward some peoples while ruthless toward others
Flamininus was ordered by the Senate to completely destroy Greece as he had been instructed
Rome's actions were driven by more than simple military dominanceâ€”political and cultural factors mattered
Rome viewed Carthage as fundamentally alien in ways it didn't view Greece
Rome treated all conquered peoples and rivals identically regardless of circumstances
Rome's choice of policies reflected judgments about long-term stability and control

questions.question: What did Rome's simultaneous warfare against multiple powers reveal about its institutional capacity compared to other ancient empires? (SELECT ALL THAT APPLY)
options: Rome's military organization was inherited from Alexander the Great
Rome possessed superior organizational systems for coordinating multiple military theaters
Rome could sustain warfare across vast distances with logistical support
Most ancient powers would have been overwhelmed by Rome's challenges
This institutional capacity explained Rome's rise more than superior tactics alone
All ancient powers possessed comparable institutional capacity but Rome had better generals

questions.question: How did Rome's political decision-making process regarding Carthage's destruction reflect both rational strategic calculation and irrational fear? (SELECT ALL THAT APPLY)
options: Rational: Carthage was economically recovering and could eventually become dangerous
Psychological trauma from Hannibal's invasion created irrational fear that exceeded objective threat assessment
Rome's military dominance made Carthage pose no realistic threat regardless of economic recovery
Cato deliberately manipulated Senate emotions by invoking the Second Punic War to override rational objections
The decision was made through purely logical cost-benefit analysis with no emotional influences
Rome's fear of Carthage was entirely justified given Carthage's demonstrated military capabilities

questions.question: Evaluate the argument that Rome's Mediterranean dominance in 149 BCE contained the seeds of future Roman civil conflict. Which elements support this interpretation? (SELECT ALL THAT APPLY)
options: Successful military commanders controlling distant armies accumulated unprecedented power and influence that could challenge Senate authority and constitutional governance
The elimination of external threats that had previously unified Roman political factions created space for internal competition over the distribution of imperial wealth and provincial control
Rome's expanding territorial holdings provided sufficient resources and economic stability to prevent any serious internal political disputes or factional conflicts indefinitely
Rome's military dominance necessarily prevented any possibility of civil conflict by establishing absolute control over rival power centers
Wealth from conquered territories was distributed equally among all Roman citizens, eliminating economic motivations for factional competition
Provincial administration and military command of distant legions became sources of power and wealth that ambitious individuals and factions could leverage against political rivals

questions.question: How did the concept of 'Pax Romana' emerge from Rome's military dominance, and what tensions did it create? (SELECT ALL THAT APPLY)
options: Peace under Roman hegemony came at the cost of eliminating all rivals and potential challengers
Rome achieved genuine universal peace throughout the empire without requiring military force to maintain control
Conquered peoples voluntarily embraced Roman rule and accepted dominance out of admiration and cultural preference
The peace enabled internal Roman political conflicts to emerge because external enemies no longer unified political factions
Pax Romana meant complete absence of any conflict or military operations anywhere in the Mediterranean world
Rome's hegemonic peace eliminated the need for any military presence or garrison forces once dominance was established
questions.text_reference: Section 10 - The Beginning of Rome's New Era
